bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Allen and Oliver, a general store located at King and Queen Court House, sold groceries, dry goods, hardware, china, glassware, and boots; also, wood was purchased and shipped from the docks at the Courthouse Landing. The store ceased operating in 1974. Its owners were Roland D. Allen and Claibourne H. Oliver (1886-1974).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Records, 1849-1955, of the Allen and Oliver company in King and Queen County, Virginia. Includes daybooks, journals, ledgers, purchase journals, journal of shad sales, and account books. A farm journal, 1872- 1888, appears to be for Benvenue Farm and may have been kept by Spottswood Bird. A memorandum book, 1883-1888, notes payments made, mail received and sent, and ship loadings and departures. In some instances, copies of letters sent have been transcribed in the memorandum book.

Correspondence includes letters, statements of account, and orders for the various firms with which the company dealt. Correspondents include American Lumber Company; Bird, Ford and Company (Del.); Chesapeake Pulp and Paper Company (Va.); C.R. Disharoon Company (Md.); Henry P. Havens, ship broker (NY); and Ryland and Brooks Lumber Company (Md.). Personal and business correspondence of Spottswood Bird is also included. Among family correspondents are Bird's sister, Ella Purcell, his sons, Spottswood Bird, Jr., Albert, Clifford, and Temple Bird, and his daughter Jean.
